title: Introduction to Computational Social Science
text:
Learning Objectives
Each module in this course has it’s own specific learning objectives. You can find them at the top of each module overview page (accessible from the Modules menu item on the course website).

title: Introduction to Computational Social Science
text:
Readings

Do we want to keep the book subdirectory, or just the learning modules page?

title: Introduction to Computational Social Science
text:
Research Software

Update for R, etc.

We will use Python and other open source software in this course. You can find details on installing and setting up your research software here. Note that Module 2 is focused on installing, setting up, and getting started with the required software.

title: Introduction to Computational Social Science
text:
Welcome to the course website for FCIT 607: Data, Methods, and Models for Future Cities! This couse is a graduate-level introduction to reproducible research, modelling, and quantitative data analysis with an emphasis on causal, probabilistic, and futures thinking. It’s part of the Master of Future Cities (MFC) program offered by the Faculty of Environment at the University of Waterloo. You can access all course materials on this site for free, including the course syllabus, overviews of each learning module, lecture slides, and an open access textbook (currently in draft form).
You can learn a bit more about me and my approach to teaching modelling and quantiative data analysis here.

title: Data, Methods, and Models for Future Cities
section: The Master of Future Cities (MFC) Program
text:
The Master of Future Cities (MFC) Program






The Future is Unknown



“The traditional approaches to studying, planning, managing, and visioning our cities are arguably struggling to address our challenges today and lack the capacity to critically explore and develop alternatives for a future city. There is need to move beyond the silos within cities and disciplinary boundaries to foster multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary thinking applied to urban challenges and futures.”
Learn more about the program here.
